metadata.titleEn: Qilian Mountains integrated observatory network: Dataset of Heihe integrated observatory network (phenology camera observation data set of Daman Superstation-2020)
metadata.description:
The dataset contains the phenological camera observation data of the Daman Superstation in the midstream of Heihe integrated observatory network from January 1, 2020 to December 31, 2020. The instrument was developed and data processed by Beijing Normal University. The phenomenon camera integrates data acquisition and data transmission functions. The camera captures data by look-downward with a resolution of 1280×720. For the calculation of the phenology, firstly, the phenological index needs to be calculated according to the region of interest. Such as, the relative greenness index (GCC, Green Chromatic Coordinate, calculated by GCC=G/(R+G+B)). Then, controlling the quality of data, filling the invalid value and filtering smoothing are performed. Finally, the key phenological parameters are determined according to the growth curve fitting, such as the growth season start date, peak, growth season end, etc. This data set includes the relative greenness index (GCC) in 2020.
Please refer to Liu et al. (2018) for sites information in the Citation section.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Definition.Question: What does 'phenocam observation dataset' mean in the context of surface process observation networks?
Definition.Answer: A 'phenocam observation dataset' refers to data collected using a phenology camera, which captures images to monitor vegetation changes over time. In the context of surface process observation networks, this involves using cameras installed vertically to gather high-resolution images at specified frequencies. The images are processed to calculate phenological indices such as the Relative Greenness Index (GCC), which is used to determine key phenological parameters like the start and end of the growing season.

Definition.Question: What is 'eddy covariance system' as a data collection method in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Definition.Answer: An 'eddy covariance system' is a method used to measure and analyze turbulent fluxes of energy, water vapor, and carbon dioxide between the land surface and atmosphere. In oasis–desert ecosystems, this system is employed to gather half-hourly data on these fluxes, providing insights into energy, water, and carbon exchanges that are crucial for understanding ecological interactions and carbon balance.

Definition.Question: What does 'data quality control' entail in the context of hydrometeorological data collection?
Definition.Answer: In the context of hydrometeorological data collection, 'data quality control' involves processes to ensure the accuracy and reliability of collected data. This includes quality checks, filling in missing or invalid values, and applying filters to smooth the data. These steps are critical in maintaining the integrity of datasets that include variables like radiation, soil heat flux, and meteorological parameters.

Comparison.Question: How do the challenges faced in maintaining data accuracy in the inland river basins of arid regions compare to those in managing oasis–desert ecosystem datasets?
Comparison.Answer: Inland river basins face challenges such as ecological degradation, which may affect data accuracy, while oasis–desert ecosystems require careful monitoring of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges to ensure data accuracy and support ecological security, emphasizing the importance of long-term observations.

Interpretation.Question: What data collection methods could be inferred to maintain a balance between oasis and desert systems for sustainable development?
Interpretation.Answer: The data collection methods involve acquiring long-term observational datasets consisting of energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data such as hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters, using tools like eddy covariance systems and automatic weather stations.

Interpretation.Question: What characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange datasets are essential for supporting ecological security and sustainable development in oasis-desert ecosystems?
Interpretation.Answer: Essential characteristics include robust data processing and quality control, encompassing data collection, processing, archiving, and sharing, as well as the inclusion of detailed parameters such as radiation, soil heat flux, temperature profiles, and vegetation and soil parameters.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes challenges in maintaining the ecological balance between oasis and desert systems?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The challenges in maintaining the ecological balance between oasis and desert systems are due to the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, particularly in inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it important to have long-term observations in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Long-term observations are important in oasis–desert ecosystems to achieve a quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange. This understanding is crucial for recognizing oasis–desert interactions and is significant for protecting the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of using phenology cameras for data collection on the accuracy and completeness of vegetation growth cycle observations in arid regions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using phenology cameras can provide detailed temporal resolution and accuracy in observing vegetation growth cycles by capturing data at specified time frequencies and resolutions. This method allows for precise calculation of phenological indicators such as the Green Chromatic Coordinate (GCC), which can enhance the understanding and monitoring of key growth parameters like the start and end of the growing season, thus improving the accuracy of vegetation observations in arid regions.

Causal Consequence.Question: What might be the implications of climate change on the data collected from inland river basins in arid areas with regards to ecological environment degradation?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The data collected from inland river basins in arid areas can reflect the impacts of climate change on ecological environments, such as drying rivers and lakes, vegetation degradation, and intensified desertification. These changes may be exacerbated by climate change, leading to an increased frequency of dust storms and other ecological crises. Long-term observational datasets are crucial to understanding these trends and developing strategies to mitigate negative impacts.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the goals behind collecting long-term observational datasets in oasis–desert systems, particularly concerning energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary goal is to achieve a quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems to recognize the interactions within these systems. This understanding is crucial for maintaining ecological stability and supporting sustainable development in these areas. It also supports the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality and ensures ecological security.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to address challenges in data collection within arid and semiarid regions, especially for ecosystems in inland river basins?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Arid and semiarid regions, particularly inland river basins, face ecological degradation challenges like drying rivers and intensified desertification. Addressing these challenges is essential to mitigate environmental degradation, support ecological restoration, and maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems, which is vital for ecological and socioeconomic stability.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why does the collection of half-hourly turbulent flux data from oasis–desert systems utilize both eddy covariance systems and scintillometers?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The use of both eddy covariance systems and scintillometers aims to obtain a comprehensive and accurate representation of the energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane fluxes. This dual approach enhances the reliability of data collection and helps in capturing the complex interactions in oasis–desert ecosystems, which is critical for understanding and managing these environments.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What instrumental techniques are applied to gather energy, water vapor, and carbon flux data in oasis–desert systems?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Energy, water vapor, and carbon flux data in oasis–desert systems are gathered using a combination of eddy covariance systems and scintillometers. These instruments provide half-hourly turbulent flux data. Moreover, automatic weather stations supply supplementary hydrometeorological data, which include radiation, soil heat flux, temperature profiles, and gradients of air temperature and humidity among other parameters.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are followed to ensure data quality in long-term observations of oasis–desert ecosystems?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The data quality in long-term observations of oasis–desert ecosystems is ensured through a structured process that includes data collection, processing, and archiving. The procedure involves acquiring data from various instruments, applying data processing techniques to handle raw measurements, and employing quality control measures such as filling gaps and smoothing data. Finally, the processed data is archived and shared for broader accessibility.

Enablement.Question: What conditions and resources are necessary to maintain long-term energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Enablement.Answer: Long-term observations are crucial, requiring a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems, including energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters. The presence of an eddy covariance system and scintillometer is also necessary.

Enablement.Question: How do advancements in phenological camera technology enable the precise calculation of key phenological parameters in arid regions?
Enablement.Answer: The phenological camera, developed by Beijing Normal University, integrates data acquisition and transmission functionalities, capturing images at a resolution of 1280x720. It enables the calculation of phenological indicators such as the Green Chromatic Coordinate (GCC) by processing images through quality control, invalid value filling, and filtering to determine key phenological parameters like growth season start and end dates.

Enablement.Question: What technological and methodological developments support the integration and sharing of hydrometeorological and flux data in arid inland river basins?
Enablement.Answer: The establishment of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations since 2012 supports data collection. Automatic weather stations and systems such as the eddy covariance system provide half-hourly and 10-minute average data. The data processing involves steps like collection, processing, archiving, and sharing, with the dataset available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Expectation.Question: Why might researchers expect challenges in maintaining the balance between oasis and desert systems while collecting data in arid and semiarid regions?
Expectation.Answer: Challenges arise from ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, intensification of land desertification, and frequent dust storms, especially in inland river basins in these regions.

Expectation.Question: What expectations might researchers have regarding the availability and quality of long-term observational datasets in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Expectation.Answer: Researchers might expect long-term observational datasets to be indispensable for understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange, which is crucial for achieving carbon peaking and carbon neutrality goals, supporting ecological security, and ensuring sustainable development of oases.

Expectation.Question: Why might it be expected that advanced data collection methods are necessary for accurately capturing energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes in oasis–desert systems?
Expectation.Answer: Advanced data collection methods, such as eddy covariance systems and scintillometers, are necessary to accurately capture these metrics due to the complex interactions within oasis–desert systems and the need for high-resolution temporal data to inform quantitative understanding and ecological stability.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of the data collection methods utilized in observing energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Judgmental.Answer: The data collection methods, which include an eddy covariance system and scintillometer for turbulent flux data, and automatic weather stations for hydrometeorological data, offer a comprehensive approach. They allow for detailed long-term observations that are crucial for understanding the complex interactions in oasis–desert ecosystems, thereby supporting ecological stability and sustainable development.

Assertion.Answer: The data processing techniques that ensure quality and reliability involve multiple steps: data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing. These steps include quality control procedures such as data validation, filtering, and smoothing, which help to maintain the integrity of the datasets collected from oasis–desert regions.

Request/Directive.Question: Please summarize the data collection techniques used for observing energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems.
Request/Directive.Answer: The data collection techniques for observing energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems involve a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural systems. Long-term datasets include energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane fluxes, supplemented by hydrometeorological data, vegetation, and soil parameters. Half-hourly turbulent flux data are obtained using an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. Hydrometeorological data such as radiation, soil heat flux, soil temperature, air temperature, humidity gradients, wind speed and direction, air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles are collected from automatic weather stations with a 10-minute average period. Additionally, groundwater table data and other relevant parameters are included.

Request/Directive.Question: Please describe the challenges faced in data collection for ecological monitoring in inland river basins of arid and semiarid areas.
Request/Directive.Answer: The challenges faced in data collection for ecological monitoring in inland river basins of arid and semiarid areas include the crisis of ecological environment degradation. This manifests as the drying up of rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, intensification of land desertification, and frequent dust storms. These issues are particularly prevalent in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin, the Aral Sea basin, and the Lake Urmia basin.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify potential datasets that could be used to study the interactions between oasis and desert systems and their role in the global carbon cycle.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential datasets for studying the interactions between oasis and desert systems and their role in the global carbon cycle include those from the middle and lower reaches of the Heihe River Basin (HRB) in western China. These datasets, freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center, comprise energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations, as well as hydrometeorological data, vegetation, and soil parameters collected from 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations established since 2012, including 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations.
